greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Dispersion, read by antidiagonals, of the complement of row 0 of the array R in A087465.
comment: The sequence is a permutation of the natural numbers and the array is a transposable dispersion.
link: Clark Kimberling and John E. Brown, Partial Complements and Transposable Dispersions, J. Integer Seqs., Vol. 7, 2004, Article 04.1.6, 22 pp.
formula: Transpose of the array R in A087465.
mathematica: r = 20; r1 = 12;(*r=# rows of T,r1=# rows to show*);
c = 20; c1 = 12;(*c=# cols of T,c1=# cols to show*);
v = Complement[Range[Max[u]], u]; f[n_] := v[[n]]; Table[f[n], {n, 1, 30}]

mex[list_] := NestWhile[#1 + 1 &, 1, Union[list][[#1]] <= #1 &, 1,   Length[Union[list]]]; rows = {NestList[f, 1, c]}; Do[rows = Append[rows, NestList[f, mex[Flatten[rows]], r]], {r}]; w[i_, j_] := rows[[i, j]]; TableForm[Table[w[j, i], {i, 1, 10}, {j, 1, 10}]]   (*A087468 array*)
Flatten[Table[w[n - k + 1, k], {n, 1, c1}, {k, 1, n}]] (*A087468 sequence*)
results.author: _Clark Kimberling_, Sep 09 2003
